tanks.notes: Tank strength reflects El Alamein establishment (October 1942). Division fielded mix of American (Sherman, Grant, Stuart) and British (Crusader) tanks.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.notes: Two field regiments RHA, 24 guns each

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for offensive operations. Short supply lines from Alexandria (250km) gave substantial logistical advantage over Axis forces. El Alamein fought from prepared positions with forward supply dumps.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1942-Q4 (October-December) - Autumn to winter, optimal campaigning season
weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (El Alamein position), firm ground suitable for armor operations

subordinate_units.notes: At El Alamein: 24 Crusaders, 57 Grants, 31 Shermans. Three armoured regiments plus motor battalion.
Nottinghamshire Yeomanry (Sherwood Rangers), 24th Lancers, 13th/18th Hussars. Equipped with Sherman and Grant tanks.
Attached 29 September - 25 November 1942. 2nd, 4th, 5th (Cinque Ports) Battalions Royal Sussex Regiment.
24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns, attached to 24th Armoured Brigade

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured exploitation and breakthrough operations
tactical_innovations: Integration of American Sherman/Grant tanks with British organization
Lorried infantry brigade for mobile operations
Flexible brigade task organization for specific missions
known_issues: Division relatively new - formed 1941, limited combat experience pre-Alamein
Mix of tank types (Sherman, Grant, Crusader) complicates logistics and maintenance
Grant tank's high silhouette and sponson-mounted gun limits tactical flexibility
Coordination challenges between multiple brigade commanders
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Sun compasses, sand channels, water bowsers, fuel economy measures, dust protection for engines and optics, desert camouflage schemes

operations.name: Battle of Alam Halfa
operations.role: Defensive battle south of El Alamein, 22nd Armoured Brigade attached
operations.outcome: Success - Rommel's offensive halted with heavy losses

operations.name: Second Battle of El Alamein (Operation Lightfoot)
operations.role: Breakthrough operations, exploitation through Axis lines
operations.outcome: Decisive victory - Axis forces routed, pursuit into Libya

operations.name: Pursuit to Libya
operations.role: Advance guard pursuing retreating Axis forces westward
operations.outcome: Ongoing - captured Tobruk, continued pursuit to Benghazi and beyond

historical_context.combat_effectiveness: Good - Division performed well at Alam Halfa (defensive) and El Alamein (offensive breakthrough). Sherman tanks provided significant firepower advantage. However, coordination between brigades sometimes difficult. Division symbol: fox's mask (hunting tradition).

scenario_suitability: Second Battle of El Alamein (breakthrough operations)
special_rules: Combined Arms (+1 when infantry, armour, artillery coordinate)
Sherman Firepower (+1 tank gunnery with M4 Shermans)
Good Supply (+1 logistics, short supply lines from Alexandria)

source: Second Battle of El Alamein order of battle (Military History Database)
8th Armoured Brigade historical records (British Army archives)
British armoured division establishment 1942 (Official TO&E documents)
133rd Lorried Infantry Brigade records (British Army unit histories)
Tank strength at El Alamein (multiple historical analyses)
known_gaps: 24th Armoured Brigade commander name unknown for Q4 1942
Exact tank distribution between two armoured brigades estimated
Some subordinate unit commanders unknown (regiment/battalion level)
Precise operational vs authorized equipment counts estimated
Chief of Staff name not identified
Vehicle variant proportions estimated from standard establishments
validation.notes: Built from El Alamein order of battle records, British armoured division establishments 1942, and unit historical accounts. Division fought at Alam Halfa (defensive) and Second Battle of El Alamein (breakthrough). Mix of American Lend-Lease tanks (Sherman, Grant, Stuart) and British Crusader tanks. 133rd Lorried Infantry Brigade attached September-November 1942 specifically for El Alamein offensive.
